title: MILLER: Sarkisian's problems far beyond football field
text:
BY JEFF MILLER / STAFF COLUMNIST
Published: Oct. 11, 2015 Updated: Oct. 12, 2015 12:16 a.m. There always has been an unyielding human element to the 2015 story of Steve Sarkisian, no matter how easy dismissing it was for the rest of us.
Now, thereâs no avoiding Sarkisianâs frailties as his story turns as sad as a 41-year-old father of three trying to keep his life from going to pieces.
Sarkisianâs days as USCâs head coach should be over, his forced leave of absence announced Sunday likely the first official step toward that end.
At the moment, itâs impossible to imagine any scenario that concludes with him back in charge of a program too high-profile to be so compromised.
Judging from much of the reaction inside the Coliseum during USCâs 17-12 loss Thursday to Washington, any coaching change â" for good or just for now â" will be welcomed.
But that â" as major as all news concerning Trojansâ football seems to be â" isnât what Sarkisianâs story is about anymore.
The ghosts he faces are far more real than anything Notre Dame will throw at USC on Saturday. His problems greatly exceed any win-loss record, even one as unexpectedly underwhelming as the Trojansâ current 3-2 mark.
Sarkisian is in the middle of a divorce, according to multiple reports, a development with which he apparently is struggling to cope.
He was said to be seeking treatment for an undisclosed issue in the aftermath of his âSalute to Troyâ embarrassment, which he later blamed on a mixture of alcohol and prescription medication.
In August, Sarkisian promised he wouldnât drink anymore this season, a promise that, again according to multiple reports, he broke over the weekend.
There is no question how much Sarkisian values his job at USC, the school he repeatedly has called âhome,â a job he more than once has labeled an âhonorâ and âprivilege.â
On the day he was introduced as the Trojansâ coach in December of 2013, he reminisced about watching USC games in his college dorm room and marveled at the remarkable fortune that now had him living a dream.
Still, he was unable to prevent from happening what just happened. Thatâs how deep Sarkisianâs problems extend, these sorts of demons well known for their tireless commitment and unwillingness to die.
Nearly seven weeks ago, when he first publicly addressed the âSalute to Troyâ incident, Sarkisian refused to admit he had a problem. Hereâs hoping he is willing to admit his problem today.
He is in a very private fight, one that never should be played out in a place as public as the sidelines of a giant stadium. In that regard, Sarkisianâs situation didnât have to reach the awkward point that it did Sunday.
